content.title: Arterial System: Structure and Function
content.summary: Arteries are blood vessels that carry oxygenated blood from the heart to tissues throughout the body. They have three distinct wall layers and demonstrate elastic properties essential for maintaining blood pressure.

wall_layers.name: Tunica intima
wall_layers.description: Innermost layer consisting of endothelium and subendothelial connective tissue
wall_layers.function: Provides smooth surface for blood flow, regulates vascular tone through NO production

wall_layers.name: Tunica media
wall_layers.description: Middle layer containing smooth muscle cells and elastic fibers
wall_layers.function: Controls vessel diameter through vasoconstriction/vasodilation, provides elastic recoil

wall_layers.name: Tunica adventitia
wall_layers.description: Outermost layer of connective tissue with vasa vasorum and nervi vasorum
wall_layers.function: Anchors vessel to surrounding structures, provides nutritional supply to outer wall

arterial_types.characteristics: High elastin content, accommodate pulsatile flow
Prominent smooth muscle layer, regulate blood distribution
Major site of peripheral resistance, control tissue perfusion

content.clinical_significance: Arterial pathology underlies atherosclerosis, aneurysms, and occlusive disease - the primary conditions treated by vascular surgeons
